subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: Kuwait is seeking to shift toward a low-carbon economy by 2050, but does not currently have a net-zero goal or strategy.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: Kuwait’s updated ‘nationally determined contribution’ (NDC) – meaning its official plan to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement – aims to reduce the country’s greenhouse gas emissions by 7.4% between 2015 and 2035 versus a business-as-usual scenario. The sectors being targeted for mitigation are energy, industrial processes, agriculture and forestry and other land use.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: Kuwait does not have a fossil fuel phase-out policy.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: Kuwait’s power generation capacity is primarily based on fossil fuels, namely oil, diesel and natural gas. The country’s 2030 Energy Strategy aims to secure 15% of power generation from renewable energy resources by 2030, and Kuwait has implemented a public-private partnership program to increase renewables capacity. However, only one tender was awarded for a 1.5 gigawatt solar project in 2018, and the project has since been stopped due to Covid-19.

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: Electricity is heavily subsidized in Kuwait, with the government covering around 90-94% of the cost. This subsidy is seen as a right of citizenship by Kuwaitis, so efforts to decrease the level of support have historically been met with resistance.

subsections.title: Power market
text: Kuwait has a 100% electrification rate and a peak power demand of 15 gigawatts. The power market is dominated by the Ministry of Electricity and Water, hence there is no competitive retail market. Retail licenses do not appear to be available in Kuwait, as rooftop solar PV is only for self-use. Transmission is also provided by the government.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Fossil fuels are subsidized, and there is no single entity that has been mandated to set a strategy for increasing renewable capacity, creating a fragmented environment.

subsections.title: EV market
text: Kuwait’s government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the electric vehicle (EV) market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantial policy support in the sector and the EV market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: A lack of charging infrastructure is a barrier to EV uptake – the country currently only has 4-5 charging stations. The cost of gasoline is also extremely low, meaning that purchasing an EV is not an economical choice.

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: Kuwait is currently working to increase the energy efficiency of its buildings. Government buildings are required to source 10% of their energy from renewables, and the country has also implemented the Renewable Building Code and Green Building Code.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the low-carbon heat market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: There are no loans or grants available to support buildings efficiency efforts.
